sentence: New York State Governor Andrew Cuomo and New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio are popping corks now that Amazon.com (AMZN) has selected New York City as the location for a second headquarters.
Arlington, Va., just outside of Washington D.C., was the other winner of the Amazon HQ sweepstakes.
The New York leaders touted $3.6 billion in direct investment, 107,000 jobs, $14 billion in state tax revenue and $13.5 billion in City tax revenue.
They believe those numbers work out to a return on investment ratio of 9:1.
The investment here being forgone are state and local income taxes on Amazon's earnings.
It seems the deal is universally positive for the New York economy.
Or is it?
Harvard Assistant Professor of Business Administration Ethan Rouen co-wrote a paper this year that concluded corporate tax cuts increase income inequality.
Part of the reason appears to be that some of the tax benefits are retained by business owners.
It's good for the shareholders, but they may not be part of the local community.
Also, the local benefits may not trickle down to all community members.
And there is also an old joke that goes something like, "Every time a tech company goes public, San Francisco real-estate prices go up."
It's funny because it's true.
The S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller San Francisco Home Price NSA Index is up 23% from its pre-credit crisis peak.
Professor Rouen said to Barron's in an email that his team didn't look at housing-price impacts specifically in their paper.
Income inequality has been a continuing problem in San Francisco.
Proposition C was a ballot issue this year that proposed raising taxes on companies with over $50 million in revenue to fund homeless services.
It passed on Nov. 6 by a vote of 195,875 to 126,192.
Not all the businesses were upset with its passage.
Salesforce.com (CRM) Chairman and Co-CEO Marc Benioff has been a vocal advocate in favor of the new corporate tax.
Apparently, not all CEOs seem to feel the same on the issue.
Amazon halted expansion plans in Seattle because of a city council plan to charge large employers $500 per head to combat that city's homelessness problem.
The city council passed a tax of $275 per head in May, but repealed it less than a month later.

Seattle Councilmember Lisa Herbold's office told Barron's in an email that the tax was repealed, in part, because "to try to fight it and then lose would create a public mandate that would likely last for a generation, and would not build momentum but instead would jeopardize future efforts to pass progressive revenue options."
Tax and accounting expert Robert Willens told Barron's in a phone interview that states and localities are always on the lookout for revenue.
Especially now that there is limited deductibility for state taxes on federal returns.
That makes it tougher to raise taxes on residents.
For example, states are being more aggressive with formulas that allocate a company's revenue to their state.
He suspects that the form of the head taxes may have been counterproductive.

"[States and localities] don't always raise rates, they do things that are more subtle," said Willens

Then in September, Amazon founder and CEO Jeff Bezos pledged $2 billion for homelessness and schools.
Maybe instead of taxation, localities should try to sell their corporate residents on the reputational benefits of philanthropy?
Perhaps, but in a separate interview Salesforce's Benioff said "philanthropy can only go so far."
So, the public/private debate rages on.
And, of course, there is academic debate as well with literature that supports corporate-tax breaks.
For example, the Federal Reserve wrote a paper in January 2018 that indicates lower corporate tax rates help innovation.
So it's easy to see why New York is so excited.
9:1 is a tremendous return on investment.
Still, it makes one wonder just why Amazon left so much on the table.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
